731674f-b.title: Feast of Saint Anthony of Padua, No. 7-9.
731674f-b.text:
(1)
Feast of St. Anthony of Padua, 1924, No. 7. A statuette of St. Anthony, conventionalized as usual in Franciscan habit and with a Child on his right arm, flanked by statuettes of
Columbia and Italia.
September 1, 1924.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
No. 8. Outdoor shrine of St. Anthony, showing offerings of paper money pinned to the statue of the saint and to that of
the Child on his arm.
September 1, 1924.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
No. 9. The same, another view. The place is First Avenue
and 106th Street.
September 1, 1924.
P. L. Sperr.

731678f-a.title: Feast of Saint Anthony of Padua.
731678f-a.text:
(1)
Feast of St. Anthony of Padua, 1926, No. 1. The tower, surrounded by the crowd, in 1Ooth Street east of First Avenue.
This year the feast was held on Labor Day.
September 6, 1926.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
No. 2. Balloon vendor in 1Ooth Street at First Avenue, the
tower is seen in the background.
September 6, 1926.
P. L. Sperr.

731678f-b.title: Feast of Saint Anthony of Padua.
731678f-b.text:
(1)

tower is seen in the background.

P. L. Sperr.

731680f-a.title: Feast of Saint Anthony of Padua.
731680f-a.text:
Feast of St. Anthony of Padua, 1927, No. 4. A close view of the front of the tower as it is carried across First Avenue. Notice the number of men it takes to support it. Musicians are seated at the base of the tower in front of the statue
of St. Anthony.
September 5, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
No. 5. Shrine to St. Anthony on First Avenue near 106th Street. Candles burn before the statue, and two votive images of wax, representing legs, are hung, one on either side of the statue. A small floral boat, flying the American and the Italian flags, may be seen on the right; and the usual offerings of
paper money are pinned to St. Anthony's robe.
September 5, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.

731680f-b.title: Feast of Saint Anthony of Padua.
731680f-b.text:
Feast of St. Anthony of Padua, 1927, No. 4. A close view of the front of the tower as it is carried across First Avenue. Notice the number of men it takes to support it. Musicians are seated at the base of the tower in front of the statue
of St. Anthony.
September 5, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
No. 5. Shrine to St. Anthony on First Avenue near 106th Street. Candles burn before the statue, and two votive images of wax, representing legs, are hung, one on either side of the statue. A small floral boat, flying the American and the Italian flags, may be seen on the right; and the usual offerings of
paper money are pinned to St. Anthony's robe.
September 5, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.

731682f-b.title: Feast of Saint Anthony of Padua.
731682f-b.text:
(1)
Feaat of St. Anthony of Padua, 1W226, No. 4. The tower, being carried in the procession on 10th Street, moving west towards First Avenue. It takes three to four dozen men to carry it. A seven or eight piece band is riding in front, under the statue of St. Anthony. The boys who manage the ropes also
ride on the tower.
Only the two lower sections of the tower are shown. A bishop, with mitre and crozier, occupies the face of the tower in the
section above St. Anthony.
September 3, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
No. 3. The same, a closer view, taken as the statue arrives alongside 401 East 1Ooth Street, adjoining the corner of
First Avenue.
The camera is close enough to show how the weight of the tower is distributed onto the shoulders of the bearera. Notice also the man in shirt sleeves and straw hat, riding in front among the musicians; he is evidently rendering or leading a song.
September 3, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
NO RaPRODUCTIONS.  RT22:  1P (Eff ](15(44-  N  11 G 1
(3)
No. o. A close rear view of the tower, which is in about the aame position as in view No. 3, but has been turned to face north. Tho bearers are resting, leaning on the heavy cosspoles by which they lift the whole structure.
Septemben 3, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.

731683f-c.title: Feast of Saint Anthony of Padua.
731683f-c.text:
(1)
Feast of St. Anthony of Padua, 1928, No. 7. The tower in procession, headed east on 1Ooth Street just west of First Avenue, and almost surrounded by a dense crowd of spectators.
September 3, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.  EE  1 rS .v) '7  14- 1S, G1
1-e -4-T ) 2
(2)
No. 8. Another view of the same crowd of spectators. The view is north on First Avenue, from and including the N.E.
corner of 106th Street.
September 3, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
No. 9. Sunday scene on the south side of 106th Street, just west of First Avenue, the day before the festival. A woman with watermelons for sale is sitting on an orange crate resding
the comics.
The church a few doors down is the Italian Presbyterian Church
of the Ascension.
September 2, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.

731689f-a.text:
(1)
Feast of St. Anthony of Fadua, 1930, No. 5. The tower at rest in 106th Street, the Saturday of Labor Day week-end.
Auguat 30, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
No. 5. Detail of the front of the tower, where St. Anthony, as usual, occupies the position of honor. Notice the sphinx on either side of him. This view was taken during the procession on Labor Day.
September 1, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
No. 7. Detail of the front and right side of the tower, and
the men carrying it.
September 1, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

taken at 106th Street and First Ave.
October 1, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

731670f-a.title: Feast of Saint Anthony of Padua - [Festa Dei Bruscianesi.]

731670f-c.title: Feast of Saint Anthony of Padua - [Festa Dei Bruscianesi.]

731670f-b.title: Feast of Saint Anthony of Padua - [Festa Dei Bruscianesi.]

731669f-b.title: Feast of Saint Anthony of Padua - [Festa Dei Bruscianesi.]
731669f-b.text:
(1)
Feast of St. Anthony of Padua, 1923, No. 1: This festival, portrayed in this and subsequent views, is not the regular feast of St. Anthony of Padua, which according to the Church calendar, should occur on June 13. This has its origin in an early September festival brought over to this country by immigrants from Brusciano, a suburb of Naples. The Bruscianese settled around 106th Street and First Avenue, and evidently found Labor Day week-end a convenient time for their annual festival. On Saturday they prepare the tall tower, and also parade their statue of St. Anthony around the upper east side Italian section. Then on Monday (Labor Day) the tower is carried back and forth on 1Obth Street; and an enormous crowd
turns out for it.
This festival in 1923 is the fifth annual Festa dei Bruscianesi (Festival of the Bruscianese). It will be held here every year until 1932, when the children will have a little Festa of their own, financial stringency inhibiting their elders. There will be one wore Festa in 1934, but not in 1955; the opinion of the neighborhood in 1935 seems to be that it will not be continued as a regular
annual affair.
The first picture shows the boat (evidently part of the saint's legend), which is carried in the procession. St. Anthony stands in the center; and the mast is surnuounted by an eagle. Notice the fine
figurehead, representing a two-tailed mermaid.
The view is east on 10oth Street, east of First Avenue. See No. 8.
September 3, 1923.
P. L. Sperr.
NV2 ~2035
(2) (2
No. 2. The boat, during the noon hour pause of the procession.
September 3, 1923.
L. Sperr.
Nk ~ 20I.
(3) 1
No. 3. Offering at a shrine of St. Anthony - a 1ittle floral boat.
September 2, 1923.
L. Sperr.

731671f-a.title: Feast of Saint Anthony of Padua.
731671f-a.text:
(1)
Feast of St. Anthony of Padua, 1923, No. 7. Spectators on the balconies, 106th Street, north side, east of First Avenue,
watching the procession.
September 3, 1923.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
NO. 8. The tower, a colossal monument, probably of papier wche, on a wooden skeleton. It is carried in the procession.
Surmounting the whole is a statue of St. Anthony.
The tower is here pictured on 106th Street, just east of First Avenue, the day before the procession. To the right may be seen the boat, in the position in which it was pictured in
No. 1.
September 2, 1923.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
No. 9. Detail of the tower, taken during the procession. The face shown pictures St. Anthony saving his father from death. The scene of this view is a side street just west of First Avenue.
September 3, 1923.
P. L. Sperr.

731672f-c.title: Feast of Saint Anthony of Padua.
731672f-c.text:
(1)
Feast of St. Anthony of Padua, 1924, No. 1. The tower at the start of the procession, 106th Street, east of First Avenue. This year the figure surmounting it is an allegorial representation of Peace, bearing a lily in her right hand. The six-story tenement house behind and to the right of the statue is 402 East 106th Street, on the south side.
This year the feast was held on Labor Day.
September 1, 1924.
P. L. Sperr.
Ng ~~2s7
(2)
No. 2. A closer view of the front of the tower as it is borne west across First Avenue by the procession. The view
is southeast.
September 1, 1924.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.  rE ,  1P'5 .  w 3  ( R E. 91S(  NE
(3)
No. 3. The tower being carried by the procession, which is RiOVing west on 1Ooth Street just after crossing First Avenue. This is a fairly close view of the right side of the statue.
September 1, 1924.
P. L. Sperr.

731676f-b.title: Feast of Saint Anthony of Padua.
731676f-b.text:
(1)
Feast of St. Anthony of Padua, 1925, No. 1. The tower, at rest in 106th Street east of First Avenue, Saturday of Labor Day week-end. A new tower is built for this feast each September. This year the tower is surmounted by a statue of St. Michael
treading on the Devil.
September 5, 1925.
L. Sperr.
Neg. ~ 2050
(2)
No. 2. Rear view of the tower, in the final stages of construction; it is standing on 106th Street at First Avenue, facing west. The rear of the tower will be covered with paper flowers.
September 5, 1925.
L. Sperr.
(3)
No. 3. A life-sizze statue of St. Anthony, with offerings of dollar bills pinned to his robe and to the Child's clothes. This is the statue pictured in 1924, 1927, and 1930. In this view it is standing in front of 323-325 East 106th Street. The parading of this statue through the streets is the annual
feature of Satunday's festivities.
September 5, 1925.
P. L. Sperr.
( pE 5    ) PEy-5gE)
( E 2P1S5  11:
11 2

731679f-c.text:
(1)
Feast of St. Anthony of Padua, 1927, No. 1. The tower, at rest in 106th Street, east df First Avenue. The feast this year,
the ninth annual feast, was held on Labor Day.
September 5, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.

First Avenue.
September 5, 1927.

towards Second Avenue.
